title: The Fabulists by Michael Peel review: a guide to dictators and their tall tales
text:
Scholars of the cultural chasm laid bare by Brexit and Trump often refer to citizens of “Anywhere” and citizens of “Somewhere”. “Somewheres” still cherish a sense of belonging, be it provincial England or small-town America, and see flags, passports and borders as part of their identity. “Anywheres” tend to be liberal, worldly, well-travelled metropolitan types, for whom all that patriotic stuff is a throwback.

As with all political taxonomies, nobody quite fits into one box perfectly, but for an example of a paid-up Anywhere, one might do worse than pick Michael Peel, Europe correspondent of the Financial Times, who over 20 years has manned FT bureaus from Lagos to Bangkok.
